text: This guide explains the difference between Generative BI (Gen BI) and Agentic Analytics, with examples, use cases, roadmap, and example architectures.

7 ğŸ› ï¸ Key Building Blocks

title: Agentic AI
text:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is evolving rapidly, and one of the most exciting developments is the emergence of Agentic AI. Unlike traditional AI systems that simply respond to input, Agentic AI systems can reason, plan, act, and adapt autonomously. This blog post will walk you through the basics of Agentic AIâ€”what it is, how it works, how it differs from other AI approaches, and why it matters.



Agentic AI refers to intelligent systems that act with intent, autonomy, and adaptability to achieve defined goals. Unlike traditional AI, these agents not only respond to commands but also plan, decide, and act proactively â€” often without step-by-step human direction.
They can perceive their environment, break down complex objectives into manageable tasks, interact with tools and APIs, and adapt their behavior based on feedback and context. In essence, they function as proactive collaborators, not just reactive assistants.
Google Cloud defines agentic AI as systems with memory, planning, and tool-use capabilities, operating in dynamic feedback loops. IBM and McKinsey emphasize their role as organizational actors â€” capable of taking initiative, making decisions aligned with goals, and integrating seamlessly with human teams.












AI Type
Behavior
Limitation




Traditional AI
Rule-based or ML-based automation
Rigid, task-specific


Generative AI
Generates text, images, audio, or video using LLMs, diffusion, GANs, etc.
Reactive: one prompt â†’ one response


Agentic AI
Goal-oriented planning and action
Proactive, multi-step autonomy







Agentic AI follows a systematic process where each step is powered by key capabilities built into the system:

Perceive â€” The agent collects and analyzes data from sensors, databases, and digital interfaces using its memory to understand the environment and identify key entities or patterns.
Reason â€” Using a reasoning engine (often an LLM) and contextual memory, the agent formulates plans, decomposes goals, and decides on the best course of action.
Plan â€” Supported by its planner, the agent organizes the tasks into a logical sequence to achieve the objective.
Act â€” The agent executes the planned tasks by interacting with external systems and APIs through its tool use capabilities.
Learn â€” Through a continuous feedback loop and updated memory, the agent monitors outcomes, learns from them, and refines its models to improve future performance.

This integrated view shows how the components are not separate modules, but enablers embedded within the steps of the agentâ€™s workflow, making the system proactive, adaptive, and goal-oriented.




Agentic AI is already transforming industries, delivering measurable benefits and enabling capabilities beyond traditional and generative AI. Below are illustrative examples and data showing how organizations are adopting and benefiting from these systems.


In financial services, agentic AI systems orchestrate the loan origination journey end-to-end, going beyond traditional AI workflows or generative AI insights. These agents: - Ingest real-time data from macroeconomic trends, customer behavior, regulatory changes, and sentiment analysis. - Assess creditworthiness, adjust pricing, recommend optimal product bundles, and flag anomalies for human review. - Collaborate with other agents in fraud detection, compliance, and capital allocation to optimize outcomes.
In operations and customer service, agents dynamically rebalance workloads across call centers, resolve customer inquiries with contextual and emotionally intelligent responses, escalate only when human judgment is needed, and detect emerging patterns (e.g., loan performance divergence) before humans are even aware.
In multiagent systems, a decentralized network of agents collaborate â€” one assessing creditworthiness, another modeling risk exposure, and a third ensuring compliance â€” working together to optimize customer journeys and manage trade-offs in real time.





With great autonomy comes greater responsibilityâ€”and risk.

Unintended Autonomy: Agents may act without proper oversight
Bias and Hallucinations: Decisions may be based on flawed or biased reasoning
Privacy Concerns: Tool-using agents must handle sensitive data with care
Brand Consistency: In customer contexts, inappropriate tone or overpersonalization can damage trust






Bounded Autonomy: Define task scope and tool permissions
Human-in-the-loop: Require approvals for high-stakes decisions
Audit Trails: Log all agent actions for transparency and review
Brand & Tone Governance: Use tone filters for customer-facing agents
Scenario Testing: Evaluate agent behavior in simulated environments
Collaborative Governance: Assign oversight responsibilities to cross-functional teams





From the Agentic Artificial Intelligence book: - Start with pilot programs in controlled environments - Use hybrid humanâ€“AI workflows to maintain oversight while leveraging automation - Scale gradually while building internal support through demonstrated success - Encourage agents and employees to learn from each other for continuous improvement






Google Cloud. (2024). What are AI agents?

IBM Think. (2024). What is Agentic AI?

IBM Think. (2024). Agentic AI vs.Â Generative AI

McKinsey & Company. (2024). When can AI make good decisions? The rise of AI corporate citizens

McKinsey & Company. (2024). The future of work is agentic

McKinsey & Company. (2024). The future of customer experience: Embracing agentic AI

Bornet, et al.Â (2024). Agentic Artificial Intelligence. Selected pages.
